initial_story:
A US Army soldier stationed in South Korea has been detained in Russia, the US military says.

The Russian foreign ministry said the charges were not related to "politics or espionage", but to a "purely domestic crime".

The 34-year-old was not on official travel when he was held on 2 May in the city of Vladivostok, in Russia's Far East.

Sgt Black had been in the process of changing duty stations from South Korea to Fort Cavazos in the US state of Texas, according to a statement from the US Army.

But instead of returning to the US, he travelled through China to Vladivostok for personal reasons, US Army spokeswoman Cynthia Smith said in a statement.

According to Russian media, he was visiting a woman with whom he had a romantic relationship.

The soldier's mother, Melody Jones, confirmed to CBS that he was in Russia visiting his girlfriend.

"Please do not torture him [or] hurt him," Melody Jones said when asked about her message to the Russians.

Sgt Black enlisted as an infantryman in 2008 and was deployed to Iraq in 2009 and Afghanistan in 2013. He was most recently assigned to the Eighth Army, US Forces Korea at Camp Humphreys in South Korea.

He did not request official clearance and the defence department did not authorise his travel to China or Russia, the US Army said. There is no evidence he intended to remain in Russia.

The Russian interior ministry informed the US embassy in Moscow on 3 May that Sgt Black had been arrested a day earlier for theft of personal property.

He is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until his next hearing.

"The Army notified his family and the US Department of State is providing appropriate consular support to the Soldier in Russia," the US Army said in a statement on Monday.

National Security Council spokesman John Kirby told reporters the US is "aware of this case and other matters related to Russia".

At the White House briefing on Monday, Mr Kirby said he could not provide more details.

Russia is holding two other Americans. Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich has been detained since March 2023 on espionage charges.

Former US Marine Paul Whelan was accused of spying and sentenced to 16 years in prison in 2020.

Both men maintain their innocence, and the US government says the charges against them are baseless.
stories: A Canadian musician touring in Brazil has been arrested by local authorities, the Canadian government says. The musician, 28-year-old Emily Wilson, was not on official business when she was detained in the city of Curitiba on 10 July, a government spokesperson said. Emily was in the process of moving from Portugal to Vancouver, British Columbia, and had stopped in Brazil for personal reasons. According to Brazilian media, she was visiting a friend with whom she had a long-standing relationship. Emily's mother, Rachel MacDonald, asked the Brazilians not to "hold her too long" or "take away her passport".

A Japanese filmmaker, known for his avant-garde style, has been detained in Paris on allegations of unauthorized filming in the city's famous Montmartre district. The 32-year-old, named Taro Matsumoto, had traveled to Europe to research a new project, but authorities say he failed to obtain the necessary permits before shooting. According to French media, Taro was capturing footage of street performers and artists, some of whom had allowed him to film them in the past. Taro's agent, Makoto Tanaka, has asked the French government to allow Taro to return to his Tokyo studio, citing concerns about the health of his ailing father, who relies on his son's care.

A French jazz musician, renowned for her improvisational talents, has been arrested in New Orleans for allegedly playing unauthorized sets on the city's iconic French Quarter streets. The 28-year-old, named Colette Dupont, had traveled to America to research a new album, but authorities say she failed to secure the necessary permits before performing. According to local music enthusiasts, Colette was busking with fellow musicians, some of whom had invited her to join them in the past. Colette's manager, Jacques Martin, has pleaded with the New Orleans city government to allow Colette to return to her Lyon studio, citing concerns about the health of her elderly mother, who relies on her daughter's care.

A British pop singer, fresh from a sold-out world tour, has been detained in Tokyo for allegedly performing without a license at the city's famous Shibuya Crossing. The 25-year-old, named Emily Thompson, had traveled to Japan to collaborate with a prominent electronic music producer, but authorities say she failed to obtain the required permits before taking to the stage. According to fans who had gathered to hear her sing, Emily was performing acoustic versions of her hit songs, with the help of a local musician who had invited her to jam together. Emily's agent, Rachel Lee, has appealed to the Tokyo city government to release Emily, citing concerns about her client's fragile mental health following a recent bout of depression.

A Spanish flamenco dancer, renowned for her fiery performances in Madrid's tablao, has been held in Morocco for allegedly performing in a public square without a permit in the historic city of Marrakech. The 30-year-old, named Sofia Morales, had traveled to North Africa to collaborate with a local oud player, but authorities say she failed to obtain the necessary approvals before taking to the stage. According to onlookers who had gathered to watch her dance, Sofia was performing an impromptu rendition of traditional flamenco styles, accompanied by the oud player on his instrument. Sofia's manager, Carlos Garcia, has requested the Marrakech city government to release Sofia, citing concerns about her client's fatigue following a grueling tour schedule.

A young American jazz musician, fresh from a tour in New Orleans, was detained in Tokyo's Shibuya district for allegedly playing an unauthorized set on a street corner. The 25-year-old, named Emily Wong, had traveled to Japan to collaborate with a local taiko drummer, but authorities claim she did not obtain the necessary permits before performing in public. Witnesses reported that Emily was improvising a fusion of traditional jazz and Japanese rhythms, backed by the taiko player on his instruments. Emily's manager, Rachel Lee, has petitioned the Tokyo Metropolitan Government to release her client, citing concerns about Emily's well-being following a demanding tour and the language barriers that may exacerbate the situation.

In the vibrant streets of Marrakech, a British singer-songwriter, 28-year-old Ava Patel, was taken into custody for allegedly performing an impromptu concert on Jemaa el-Fnaa without the required permission. Ava had traveled to Morocco to work on a new album with a local band, incorporating traditional Gnawa and Arabesque melodies into her folk-pop sound. According to eyewitnesses, she captivated the crowd with her soulful voice and ukulele, blending British balladry with Moroccan rhythms. Ava's producer, Amir Jamal, has submitted an appeal to the Marrakech authorities, expressing concerns about Ava's mental and physical exhaustion after a rigorous world tour and the potential cultural misunderstandings that could further complicate her detention.

In the secluded hills of Porto, a Portuguese jazz pianist, 35-year-old Sofia Fonseca, was detained for allegedly performing an unauthorized gig at the historic Ribeira Market, drawing in a crowd with her genre-bending improvisations. Sofia had traveled to Porto to collaborate with a local troupe of fado musicians, fusing traditional Portuguese melancholy with modern American jazz phrasing. According to witnesses, she entranced the audience with her percussive playing and emotive vocals, merging Iberian passion with American grit. Sofia's manager, Carlos Moreno, has filed a petition with the Porto authorities, stressing concerns about Sofia's post-injury fatigue and the miscommunication that has delayed her return to her awaiting family.

In the verdant valleys of Tokyo, a 28-year-old Japanese flamenco guitarist, Akira Tanaka, was detained for allegedly leading an impromptu jam session on the banks of the Sumida River, drawing in a crowd with his innovative fusions of traditional Japanese melodies and gypsy rhythms. Akira had traveled to Tokyo to collaborate with a local collective of taiko drummers, blending modern electronic beats with ancient traditional instrumentation. According to eyewitnesses, he mesmerized the audience with his intricate fingerwork and haunting harmonies, merging Asian lyricism with Latin fire. Akira's partner, Emiko Nakamura, has lodged a complaint with the Tokyo authorities, citing concerns about Akira's chronic hand cramps and the administrative delays that have stalled his plans to return to his awaiting band.

In the moonlit alleys of Marrakech, a 32-year-old Moroccan qraqeb player, Amira el-Fassi, was stopped by police for allegedly leading an illicit improvisation on the walls of the ancient Medina, entrancing passersby with her sinuous rhythms and melismatic vocals. Amira had traveled to Morocco to collaborate with a group of nomadic Berber musicians, combining electronic beats with traditional Gnawa melodies. Witnesses describe her playing as hypnotic, weaving together Arabic ornamentation with African polyrhythms. Amira's companion, Hassan el-Bahari, has appealed to the Moroccan authorities, citing concerns about Amira's recurring wrist pains and the bureaucratic hurdles that have delayed her plans to perform at the upcoming Fez Festival.

In the dimly lit speakeasy of Tokyo, a 25-year-old Japanese taiko drummer, Kenji Sato, was arrested for allegedly drumming on the city's rooftops under the guise of a nighttime rehearsal, his thunderous beats echoing through the neon-lit skyscrapers and mesmerizing pedestrians with his infectious energy. Kenji had traveled from Osaka to Tokyo to collaborate with a collective of street musicians, fusing traditional shamisen melodies with electronic sampling. Eyewitnesses recall his playing as electrifying, merging Japanese rhythms with Latin American syncopation. Kenji's friend, Yuna Kiyoto, has petitioned the Tokyo authorities, citing concerns about Kenji's recurring shoulder strain and the labyrinthine permits required to perform at the upcoming Sapporo Summer Festival.

In the sweltering heart of Marrakech's souks, a 28-year-old Berber snake charmer, Fatima Hassan, was detained for allegedly seducing the city's alleys with the hypnotic melodies of her rebab, her sinuous rhythms weaving through the fragrant mounds of jasmine and rose petals. Fatima had traveled from Fez to Marrakech to collaborate with a troupe of street performers, blending traditional gnawa chanting with the resonant hum of the darbuka. Eyewitnesses describe her playing as entrancing, merging North African cadences with Indian raga intricacies. Fatima's fellow performer, Amira Azeroual, has appealed to the Marrakech authorities, citing concerns about Fatima's recurring hand cramps and the labyrinthine permits required to perform at the upcoming Fez World Music Festival.

In the moonlit gardens of Kyoto's Fushimi Inari, a 25-year-old Japanese shamisen virtuoso, Akira Nakamura, was whisked away for allegedly conjuring the enchanted spirits of the fox-fire gods with the celestial harmonies of her shamisen, her fingers dancing across the kaniwa in intricate flourishes. Akira had traveled from Osaka to Kyoto to join forces with a troupe of taiko drummers, fusing traditional sumo chanko songs with Korean pansori melodies. Onlookers rave about her performance, describing it as transcendent, meshing Japanese scales with the tender rhythms of the shamisen. Akira's fellow performer, Hanae Matsumoto, has petitioned the Kyoto authorities, voicing worries about Akira's mysterious recurring migraines and the Byzantine permits required to perform at the upcoming Tokyo Jazz Festival.

In the gleaming cantinas of Mexico City's La Merced, a 30-year-old Mexican accordion wunderkind, Luisa Morales, was lured away from a whiskey-fueled jam session, rumored to have awakened the rebellious spirits of the Aztec fire goddesses with the cosmic airs of her accordion, her fingers weaving a mesmerizing tapestry of notes on the rasgueado. The whispers of Joseon's royal court and the fragrance of jasmine incense wafting from the ornate wooden doors of the ancestral shrine transported Ji-Hyun to a realm of royal legacy and poetic reverie, where the whispers of the night's celestial promises still lingered through the misty hills.

As the morning's golden light unfolded like a tapestry of possibility, a 32-year-old Japanese artist, Kenji Matsumoto, strolled through the sun-drenched alleys of his grandfather's rural village, his brushes dancing across the worn wooden beams of the old tea house. The whispers of Kamakura's samurai tradition and the scent of green tea leaves wafting from the rustic thatched roof of the family shrine carried Kenji to a realm of ancestral honor and artistic passion, where the promise of a new day's creation still echoed through the rustling rice fields.

As the moon's silver glow etched the night's velvety canvas, a 28-year-old Indian musician, Rukmini Patel, glided across the star-petaled courtyard of her grandmother's ancient Haveli, her fingers weaving a tapestry of melody across the ivory keyboard of her grandmother's antique piano. The whispers of Varanasi's Ganga ghats and the scent of spices wafting from the intricately carved wooden tikiyas of the family puja carried Rukmini to a realm of ancestral reverence and artistic devotion, where the promise of a new day's composition still echoed through the whispering pomegranate trees.

As the aurora's fiery brushstrokes painted the dawn's canvas, a 25-year-old Japanese chef, Kaito Matsumoto, stepped onto the veranda of his grandfather's ancestral ryokan, his hands sculpting a symphony of flavors on the worn wooden counter of his grandfather's century-old sushi bar. The murmurs of Kyoto's Arashiyama bamboo forests and the aroma of green tea wafting from the rustic ceramic yunomi of the family tea ceremony carried Kaito to a realm of ancestral tradition and gastronomical passion, where the promise of a new day's culinary masterpiece still shimmered in the misty mountains' emerald hearts.

As the velvet night's secret stitches embroidered the city's midnight sky, a 32-year-old Indian weaver, Rohini Kaur, stepped into the candlelit courtyard of her family's ancient haveli, her fingers weaving a tapestry of tales on the intricate loom of her great-aunt's century-old craft. The whispers of Old Delhi's crumbling Mughal walls and the scent of cardamom wafting from the bronze kettle of the family's evening tea ritual carried Rohini to a realm of ancestral stories and textile passion, where the promise of a new day's craftsmanship still shimmered in the minarets' gold-tipped silhouettes.

As the moonlit sea's gentle lullaby harmonized with the rhythmic chant of the villagers, a 28-year-old Japanese fisherman, Kenji Matsuda, pulled his wooden boat onto the shores of the hidden cove, his weathered hands repairing the intricate net of his great-uncle's storied craftsmanship. The whispers of Kamakura's ancient temples and the sweet aroma of sake rising from the family's ceremonial cedar box carried Kenji to a realm of coastal legends and marine wonder, where the promise of a new day's bounty still ripened beneath the sunrise's fiery horizon.

As the star-petaled path unwound its celestial tapestry across the velvety night sky, a 25-year-old Italian weaver, Sophia Fiorelli, walked the ancient stones of Piazza Navona, her calloused fingers weaving a symphony of sounds as she repurposed the threads of her great-aunt's Renaissance loom. The whispers of Bernini's baroque whispers and the heady scent of espresso wafting from the family's worn coffee grinder carried Sophia to a realm of Byzantine tales and artisans' secrets, where the promise of a new dawn's fabric still shimmered in the golden light of the city's awakening grandeur.

As the tangerine sky surrendered to the gentle rustle of silk petals, a 30-year-old Japanese artist, Akira Matsumoto, wove his way through the Shiba District's narrow alleys, his paint-splattered hands orchestrating a dance of colors as he restored the vibrant hues of his grandfather's 1950s samurai scroll. The sweet strains of traditional shamisen and the aroma of steaming matcha wafting from the vintage tea shop transported Akira to a realm of kimonos and cherry blossoms, where the promise of a new artform's silk still shone in the morning's soft beam of luminescent light.

As the amethyst moon cast its mystical glow on the crumbling limestone streets of the ancient city of Petra, a 35-year-old Jordanian artist, Fatima al-Khouri, delicately etched the swirling patterns of a ancient Nabataean script onto a parchment of worn parchment, her calloused fingers conjuring the whispers of her ancestors as she revived the forgotten art of sacred stone inscriptions. The fragrance of cardamom coffee and the haunting strains of the oud violin drifted from the intimate courtyard of the Umm Qais cafe, beckoning Fatima to a realm of moonlit cisterns and Byzantine mosaics, where the whispered secrets of the desert sands still lingered in the silence of the night.

As the vermilion sun dipped into the crimson horizon of the ancient city of Varanasi, a 25-year-old Indian artist, Kavita Nagpal, tenderly applied the golden dust of turmeric and vermilion to the delicate fingers of a papier-mâché Bodhisattva, her deft hands awakening the whispers of her guru as she revived the sacred art of henna temple illuminations. The pungent aroma of frankincense and sandalwood wafted from the candlelit courtyard of the Ahilya temple, luring Kavita to a realm of sacred ghats and ornate stupas, where the ancient secrets of the Ganges still lingered in the whispers of the misty dawn.

As the velvety darkness descended upon the sleepy town of Kyoto, a 30-year-old Japanese musician, Mika Tanaka, meticulously polished the intricate lacquerwork of a handcrafted shamisen, her fingers remembering the gentle guidance of her sensei as she revived the traditional art of Kiyomizu-dera temple lanterns. The sweet scent of incense and cherry blossoms wafted from the lantern-lined walkways of Fushimi Inari shrine, beckoning Mika to a realm of sacred torii gates and weathered stone statues, where the ancient whispers of the Japanese spirit still lingered in the autumn mist.

As the crimson sunset succumbed to the whispers of the Andes, a 25-year-old Peruvian weaver, Lucía García, tenderly caressed the supple yarn of her mother's ancient loom, her fingers dancing across the intricate patterns of the Nazca Lines as she revivified the mystical narratives of the Incas. The heady aroma of cedar and wildflowers wafted from the terraced gardens of Cusco's Sacsayhuamán, beckoning Lucía to a realm of crumbling Inca walls and weathered stone altars, where the echoes of the imperial empire's secrets still trembled in the evening fog.

As the moon cast its silvery glow over the misty mountains of Kashmir, a 22-year-old apprentice, Rohan Singh, attentively plied the smooth strands of silk and silver on his grandfather's revered silk-cumpany, his fingers weaving tales of ancient Pashmina lands and the mythical cities of the Indus Valley Civilization. The scent of saffron and rosewater wafted from the tranquil gardens of Lahore's Wazir Khan Mosque, summoning Rohan to a realm of crumbling Mughal ruins and intricately carved latticework, where the whispers of the Empire's golden age still lingered in the morning dew.

As the crimson sun descended upon the dusty dunes of Rajasthan, a 25-year-old novice, Leela Desai, tenderly arranged the vibrant threads of turmeric and indigo on her great-aunt's respected textile-atelier, her hands spinning tales of ancient Mewar kingdoms and the mythical city of Chitrakoot. The aroma of cardamom and jasmine wafted from the serene courtyards of Orchha's Raj Mandir Palace, beckoning Leela to a realm of crumbling Bundela temples and intricately carved turrets, where the whispers of the Empire's golden age still echoed in the rustling palm fronds.
